tit.e: Miyanomae Haiji ato (The ruins of Miyanomae abandoned temple)

sen.j: 宮の前廃寺跡（みやのまえはいじあと）とは広島県福山市蔵王町にある奈良時代から平安時代にかけての仏教寺院遺跡である。
sen.e: Miyanomae Haiji ato is a the remains of Buddhist temple from the Nara era to Heian era located in Zao-cho, Fukuyama City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
Miyanomae Haiji ato is a the remains of Buddhist temple that stood from the Nara era to Heian era located in Zao-cho, Fukuyama City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
Miyanomae Haiji ato is the remains of Buddhist temple that stood from the Nara era to Heian era located in Zao-cho, Fukuyama City, Hiroshima Prefecture.
sen.cmt: is a the remainsの a を削除しました。

sen.j: 国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: It is designated as a national historic site.
It is designated as a national historic site.
It is designated as a national historic site.

sen.j: 宮の前廃寺跡は、現在では地元の蔵王八幡神社のある丘陵南斜面中腹にある。
sen.e: Miyanomae Haiji ato is now located in the middle of the hill facing south, where local Zao Hachiman Jinja Shrine exists.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Miyanomae Haiji ato is now located in the middle of a south-facing hill on which the local Zao Hachiman Jinja Shrine stands.
Miyanomae Haiji ato is now located in the middle of a south-facing hill on which the local Zao Hachiman Jinja Shrine stands.
It is located at the side of an approach.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is situated to the side of the path leading to the shrine.
It is situated to the side of the path leading to the shrine.

sen.j: 1950年及び1967年に行われた発掘調査によれば、東に塔を配し、西に金堂を配する法起寺式と呼ばれる伽藍の寺院であった。
sen.e: According to excavation and research conducted in 1950 and 1967, it was a Buddhist temple called Hokki-ji-style, which included a tower in the east and a Kon-do Hall (golden hall) in the west.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to excavations conducted in 1950 and 1967, it was a Buddhist temple complex in the Hokki-ji-style, which included a tower in the east and a kon-do hall (main hall) in the west.
According to excavations conducted in 1950 and 1967, it was a Buddhist temple complex in the Hokki-ji-style, which included a tower in the east and a kon-do hall (main hall) in the west.

sen.j: 塔跡（何層であったかは不明）は一辺12.7メートル、高さ1.2メートル、金堂跡は東西24.9メートル、南北14メートルであったことが確認された。
sen.e: It was ascertained that the remains of the tower (It is unknown how many layers the tower had) were 12.7 m each side, 1.2 m high, and the remains of the Kon-do Hall were 24.9 m from the east to the west and 14 m from the south to the north.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It was ascertained that the remains of the tower (it is unknown how many layers the tower had) were 12.7m each side, 1.2m high, and the remains of the kon-do hall were 24.9m from east to west and 14m from north to south.

It was ascertained that the remains of the tower (it is unknown how many layers the tower had) were 12.7m each side, 1.2m high, and the remains of the kon-do hall were 24.9m from east to west and 14m from north to south.

sen.j: また出土遺物には、奈良、平安時代の数種類の軒瓦、「紀臣和古女」「栗栖君」などの文字を陰刻した丸瓦・平瓦・せん仏などがある。
sen.e: Several kinds of eaves end tiles in Nara era and Heian era, channel tiles, plane tiles, and thousand Buddha with inkoku (incised characters) such as "Ki no omi Wako no Musume", "Kurisu no Kimi" are excavated.

Several kinds of Nara and Heian period eaves end tiles as well as channel tiles, plane tiles and senbutsu (Japanese Buddhist images in relief on unglazed clay tiles) inscribed with characters such as 'Ki no omi Wako no Musume' and 'Kurisu no Kimi' have been excavated.

Several kinds of Nara and Heian period eaves end tiles as well as channel tiles, plane tiles and senbutsu (Japanese Buddhist images in relief on unglazed clay tiles) inscribed with characters such as 'Ki no omi Wako no Musume' and 'Kurisu no Kimi' have been excavated.

sen.j: 現在では参道が塔跡と金堂跡の間にあるが、遺跡の残存状況も良好であるため、1969年に国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: Now, there is an approach between the remains of the tower and the remains of the Kon-do Hall, and the remains were well-preserved, so in 1969, it is designated as a national historic site.
There is now a path between the remains of the tower and the remains of the kon-do hall, and as the remains had been well-preserved the area was designated a national historic site in 1969.
There is now a path between the remains of the tower and the remains of the kon-do hall, and as the remains had been well-preserved the area was designated a national historic site in 1969.

sen.j: 宮の前廃寺は、その名のとおり仏教寺院として存続しておらず、神社の境内に位置している。
sen.e: As its name suggests, Miyanomae Haiji does not exist as a Buddhist temple, and it is located in the precincts of the shrine.
As its name suggests, Miyanomae Haiji is no longer used as a Buddhist temple, and it is located in the precinct of the shrine.
As its name suggests, Miyanomae Haiji is no longer used as a Buddhist temple, and it is located in the precinct of the shrine.

sen.j: かつては「海蔵寺」の名の寺院であったとされを伝えて、「日本現報善悪霊異記」にある「深津市」、「法隆寺伽藍縁起并流記資財帳」にみる「深津荘」などの文献にある集落付近に建立されていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It used to be a temple called "Kaizo-ji Temple", and it was considered to be built near the village in the literature such as "Fukatsu City" in "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually refer to as the Nihon ryoiki), or "Fukatsuso" in "Horyu-ji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (note of origin and materials of Horyu-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: 和文の意味「あったとされを伝えて」が不明です。
sen.e: It is said that it used to be a temple called Kaizo-ji Temple, and is thought to have been built near a settlement mentioned in a literary work such as 'Fukatsu City' recorded in "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually refer to as the Nihon ryoiki) or 'Fukatsuso' recorded in "Horyu-ji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (note of origin and materials of Horyu-ji Temple).

It is said that it used to be a temple called Kaizo-ji Temple, and is thought to have been built near a settlement mentioned in a literary work such as 'Fukatsu City' recorded in "Nihon genho zenaku ryoiki" (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually refer to as the Nihon ryoiki) or 'Fukatsuso' recorded in "Horyu-ji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (note of origin and materials of Horyu-ji Temple).

sen.j: これは当地が備後国の国府の外港として栄えていた深津湾岸（近世までの郡名は「深津郡」）の港が存在していたとされており、律令時代の貴重な遺跡といえる。
sen.e: This was considered that in this place, there was a port in Fukatsu bay coast (the place was called "Fukatsu Province" till early-modern times) prospered as an outer harbor of Kokufu (ancient provincial office/capital) in Bingo Province, and they are valuable ruins in Ritsuryo era.

It is considered that in this place, there was a port on Fukatsu Bay coast (the place was called 'Fukatsu Province' until early-modern times) which prospered as an outer harbor of the Kokufu (ancient provincial office/capital) in Bingo Province, and they are valuable ruins of the Ritsuryo era.

It is considered that in this place, there was a port on Fukatsu Bay coast (the place was called 'Fukatsu Province' until early-modern times) which prospered as an outer harbor of the Kokufu (ancient provincial office/capital) in Bingo Province, and they are valuable ruins of the Ritsuryo era.
